verses.text: Now Ben-hadad king of Aram gathered all his army together. Thirty-two kings were with him, along with horses and chariots. He went up and besieged Samaria and attacked it.
verses.comment: Ben-hadad is often identified as Ben-hadad II. 'Aram' is commonly translated as 'Syria.'

verses.text: He sent messengers into the city to Ahab king of Israel, and said to him, "This is what Ben-hadad says:
verses.comment: Direct speech begins, as in the Hebrew.

verses.text: 'Your silver and your gold are mine. Your best wives and children are also mine.'"
verses.comment: Literally 'the good' or 'best' indicates what is most precious.

verses.text: The king of Israel answered, "As you say, my lord the king; I and all that I have are yours."
verses.comment: 'My lord the king' is polite address to Ben-hadad.

verses.text: The messengers came again and said, "This is what Ben-hadad says: I sent to you, saying, 'Deliver to me your silver, your gold, your wives, and your children.'
verses.comment: Direct reiteration of Ben-hadad’s demands.

verses.text: But at this time tomorrow, I will send my servants to you, and they shall search your house and the houses of your servants. Whatever is desirable in your eyes, they shall put it in their hands and take it away.'"
verses.comment: 'Desirable' translates literally 'pleasant in your eyes,' meaning valuable possessions.

verses.text: Then the king of Israel called all the elders of the land and said, "Notice, see how this man is seeking trouble, for he sent for my wives, my children, my silver, and my gold, and I did not refuse him."
verses.comment: Elders involved in royal decisions.

verses.text: All the elders and all the people said to him, "Do not listen or agree to his terms."
verses.comment: The assembly rejects Ben-hadad's demands.

verses.text: So he said to Ben-hadad’s messengers, "Tell my lord the king: 'Everything you first demanded from your servant I will do, but this thing I cannot do.'" And the messengers departed and brought the answer back to him.
verses.comment: Differentiates between the first and second demand.

verses.text: Ben-hadad sent to him and said, "May the gods do so to me and more also, if enough dust remains in Samaria for each of the people at my feet to take a handful!"
verses.comment: A Hebrew curse formula is used here.

verses.text: The king of Israel answered, "Tell him: 'Let not him who puts on his armor boast like one who takes it off.'"
verses.comment: Literal Hebrew: 'girds on his armor.' A proverb about victory not being assured.

verses.text: When Ben-hadad heard this message as he was drinking with the kings in his tents, he said to his servants, "Get ready." So they prepared to attack the city.
verses.comment: 'Drinking in the tents' implies overconfidence.

verses.text: Then behold, a prophet came near to Ahab king of Israel and said, "This is what the LORD says: Have you seen this great multitude? Behold, I will deliver it into your hand today, and you shall know that I am the LORD."
verses.comment: 'A prophet,' not named. The LORD refers to YHWH.

verses.text: Ahab said, "By whom?" The prophet said, "This is what the LORD says: By the young men of the governors of the districts." Then Ahab said, "Who shall begin the battle?" And he answered, "You."
verses.comment: The 'young men' are royal bodyguards or officers.

verses.text: Then he mustered the young men of the governors of the districts, and they were 232. After them, he mustered all the army of Israel, 7,000 men.
verses.comment: Number is precise; 7,000 echoes earlier judicial numbers.

verses.text: They went out at noon, while Ben-hadad was drinking himself drunk in the tents, he and the thirty-two kings who helped him.
verses.comment: Emphasis is on Ben-hadad’s drunkenness and carelessness.

verses.text: The young men of the governors of the districts went out first. Ben-hadad sent out, and they told him, "Men have come out from Samaria."
verses.comment: 'Sent out' means Ben-hadad dispatched scouts.

verses.text: He said, "If they have come out for peace, take them alive; or if they have come out for war, also take them alive."
verses.comment: Reflects either arrogance or a desire to capture alive for display.

verses.text: So these went out of the city, the young men of the governors of the districts, and the army that followed them.
verses.comment: Emphasizes use of select troops leading main army.

verses.text: Each struck down his man. The Arameans fled, and Israel pursued them. Ben-hadad king of Aram escaped on a horse with horsemen.
verses.comment: 'Arameans' (Syria) and 'Israel' distinctions kept.

verses.text: The king of Israel went out and struck the horses and chariots, and defeated the Arameans with a great slaughter.
verses.comment: 'Great slaughter' expresses a decisive victory.

verses.text: Then the prophet came near to the king of Israel and said to him, "Go, strengthen yourself, and consider well what you should do, for next year the king of Aram will come up against you."
verses.comment: 'Next year' literally 'at the turn of the year.'

verses.text: The servants of the king of Aram said to him, "Their gods are gods of the hills. That is why they were stronger than us. But if we fight them in the plain, surely we will be stronger than they."
verses.comment: Reflects ancient Near Eastern belief in local gods.

verses.text: Do this: remove the kings, each from his place, and put commanders in their places;
verses.comment: 'Kings' refers to vassal rulers under Ben-hadad.

verses.text: and muster an army like the army you lost, horse for horse and chariot for chariot. Then we will fight against them in the plain, and surely we will be stronger than they." He listened to their advice and did so.
verses.comment: The text repeats strategic advice given to Ben-hadad.

verses.text: In the spring, Ben-hadad mustered the Arameans and went up to Aphek to fight against Israel.
verses.comment: Spring was customary for campaigning.

verses.text: The people of Israel were mustered, supplied, and went out to meet them. The Israelites camped before them like two little flocks of goats, but the Arameans filled the land.
verses.comment: The sheep simile shows Israel's small numbers.

verses.text: Then a man of God came near and said to the king of Israel, "This is what the LORD says: Because the Arameans have said, 'The LORD is a god of the hills but not a god of the valleys,' therefore I will deliver all this great multitude into your hand, and you shall know that I am the LORD."
verses.comment: 'A man of God' often designates a prophet.

verses.text: They camped opposite each other seven days. And on the seventh day the battle was joined. The Israelites struck down one hundred thousand Aramean foot soldiers in one day.
verses.comment: Seven days could indicate ritual combat or waiting period.

verses.text: But the rest fled to Aphek, into the city, and the wall fell on twenty-seven thousand men who were left. And Ben-hadad fled and came into the city, into an inner chamber.
verses.comment: 'An inner chamber' is literally 'a room within a room.'

verses.text: Then his servants said to him, "Look, we have heard that the kings of the house of Israel are merciful kings. Let us put sackcloth around our waists and ropes on our heads and go out to the king of Israel. Perhaps he will spare your life."
verses.comment: 'Merciful kings' reference Israelite tradition of mercy.

verses.text: So they wore sackcloth around their waists and ropes on their heads, and went to the king of Israel and said, "Your servant Ben-hadad says, 'Please let me live.'" And he said, "Is he still alive? He is my brother."
verses.comment: 'Brother' here means a fellow king, not literal kin.

verses.text: Now the men were watching for a sign and quickly caught it from him and said, "Yes, your brother Ben-hadad." Then he said, "Go, bring him." Then Ben-hadad came out to him, and he caused him to come up into the chariot.
verses.comment: Ahab welcomes Ben-hadad with kingly courtesy.

verses.text: He said to him, "The cities which my father took from your father I will restore, and you may set up marketplaces for yourself in Damascus, like my father set up in Samaria." Ahab replied, "I will let you go on these terms." So he made a covenant with him and let him go.
verses.comment: 'Marketplaces' are places of commerce and treaty.

verses.text: Then a certain man of the sons of the prophets said to his neighbor by the word of the LORD, "Strike me, please." But the man refused to strike him.
verses.comment: 'Sons of the prophets' were groups under prophetic leaders.

verses.text: Then he said to him, "Because you have not obeyed the voice of the LORD, as soon as you leave me, a lion will strike you down." And as soon as he left him, a lion found him and killed him.
verses.comment: 'Obeyed the LORD' shows prophetic authority.

verses.text: Then he found another man and said, "Strike me, please." And the man struck him and wounded him.
verses.comment: Portrays obedience to prophetic command.

verses.text: So the prophet departed and waited for the king by the road, disguising himself with a bandage over his eyes.
verses.comment: The Hebrew is literally 'ashes' or a disguise on his face.

verses.text: As the king passed by, he cried out to the king, and said, "Your servant went out in the midst of the battle. Behold, a man turned aside and brought a man to me and said, 'Guard this man. If he is missing, your life shall be for his life, or else you shall pay a talent of silver.'
verses.comment: 'Your life for his life' is a common ancient Near Eastern penalty.

verses.text: But as your servant was busy here and there, the man disappeared." The king of Israel said to him, "So shall your judgment be; you have decided it yourself."
verses.comment: "You have decided it" is a legal formula continuing into the parable.

verses.text: Then he hurried to remove the bandage from his eyes, and the king of Israel recognized him as one of the prophets.
verses.comment: Revelation of prophet’s identity is key to the rebuke.

verses.text: He said to him, "This is what the LORD says: 'Because you have let go out of your hand the man whom I had devoted to destruction, therefore your life shall be for his life, and your people for his people.'"
verses.comment: 'Devoted to destruction' is Hebrew herem, a special ban.

verses.text: And the king of Israel went to his house sullen and angry, and came to Samaria.
verses.comment: 'Sullen and angry' indicates his grief and wrath.
